Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I was sitting in the ambulance bay, uniform crisp, radio at my side, ready for the next emergency call. The expectation was clear: be alert, be fast, save lives. As I sipped my coffee, my phone buzzed with a message from Mrs. Carter, a longtime parishioner. She asked if I might have time soon to talk—nothing urgent, just a need for guidance. As a priest, I knew the importance of being present, of listening, of offering comfort even before the crisis. I typed a gentle reply, promising to find a time, when the radio crackled: “Unit 3, possible cardiac arrest, respond immediately.” My heart raced. The ambulance needed me now, but so did Mrs. Carter, in a quieter, less visible way. I felt the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders—one demanding speed and action, the other patience and presence. I stared at my phone, then at the flashing lights above the ambulance, torn between the urgent call of the siren and the quiet plea for spiritual care.
